questions.text: A 35-year-old construction worker presents to the emergency department after a crush injury to his lower leg from a collapsed beam. He is in severe pain, with swelling and deformity noted on examination. Vital signs are stable. What is the drug of choice for managing his pain?

A 58-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw. He appears diaphoretic and anxious. On examination, his blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, heart rate is 110 bpm, and respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute. An ECG reveals ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Which of the following medications is the most appropriate initial treatment for his severe pain?
All of the following are true about the pharmacokinetics of morphine except?

options.label: A
options.text: Morphine is primarily metabolised by the liver.

options.label: B
options.text: Morphine has a long half-life, typically around 2-4 hours.

options.label: C
options.text: Morphine undergoes extensive first-pass metabolism when administered orally.

options.label: D
options.text: Morphine is primarily eliminated unchanged through the kidneys.

questions.correct_answer: D. Morphine is primarily eliminated unchanged through the kidneys.
questions.explanation:
Pharmacokinetic Aspect

Explanation

Metabolism

Morphine is metabolized in the liver to morphine-6-glucuronide (active) and morphine-3-glucuronide (inactive).

First-pass metabolism

Oral morphine undergoes significant first-pass metabolism in the liver, reducing bioavailability.

Half-life

The half-life of morphine is about 2-4 hours intravenously but can be longer orally due to first-pass metabolism.

Excretion

Morphine is excreted primarily as metabolites (not unchanged) through the kidneys. The majority of the drug is excreted as morphine-3-glucuronide and morphine-6-glucuronide.

Pharmacokinetics

Absorption:

  • Well-absorbed orally, intramuscularly, and subcutaneously
  • Distribution: Widely distributed throughout the body, including the CNS; plasma protein binding ~30-40%

Metabolism:

  • Primarily hepatic, via glucuronidation to morphine-3-glucuronide and morphine-6-glucuronide (active metabolites).
  • undergoes minimal metabolism when administered intravenously (bypasses first-pass metabolism).

Excretion:

  • Renal (primarily as metabolites); small amounts excreted unchanged in urine and bile.
 

Half-life: Approximately 2-4 hours

Onset of Action: Oral: 30-60 minutes; IV: 5-10 minutes

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of muscle aches, insomnia, and intense cravings for opioids. He admits to using heroin for the past five years, often injecting multiple times a day. He has attempted to quit several times but has always relapsed due to severe withdrawal symptoms. He expresses a strong desire to stop using heroin and asks for medical help to manage his addiction. Which of the following is the most effective medication for the treatment?
questions.explanation:
Opioid Deaddiction Drugs

Medication

Mechanism of Action

Methadone (DOC)

Full opioid agonist; binds to opioid receptors, providing similar effects to other opioids, preventing withdrawal symptoms and reducing cravings.

Methadone maintenance treatment has been used to treat opioid dependence.The opioid dependent patient takes a daily dose of methadone as a liquid or pill. This reduces their withdrawal symptoms and cravings for opioids.

 

Buprenorphine

Partial opioid agonist; binds to opioid receptors with a lower maximum effect than full agonists, reducing cravings and withdrawal symptoms.

Naltrexone

Opioid antagonist; blocks the effects of opioids at their receptor sites, preventing euphoria and other opioid effects.

Lofexidine and Clonidine

Alpha-2 adrenergic agonist; reduces the physical symptoms of opioid withdrawal by inhibiting the release of norepinephrine.

Dezocine

Naloxone

Nalmefene (Liver safe)

Naloxegol

Uses

1. Uremic pruritus in CKD (Nalfurafine)

2. Diarrhoea in IBS

1. Migraine (Intranasal Butorphanol)

1. Opioid deaddiction (Buprenorphine)

2. Analgesia (Dezocine)

1. Antidote for opioid poisoning (IV Naloxone)

2. Prevents relapse (Naltrexone)

3. Alcohol dependence (Nalmefene)

4. Morphine dependence, obesity (Naltrexone)

5. Opioid-induced constipation (Naloxol, methylnaltrexone)

S/E

Dysphoria or psychosis

Dysphoria or psychosis

Buprenorphine effects cannot be overcome by naloxone.

1. Naloxone: Hypertension, pulmonary oedema, arrhythmia

2. Naltrexone: Hepatotoxic

C/I

 

1. Opioid deaddiction (precipitate withdrawal)

2. Myocardial ischemia

Labor pain (neonatal respiratory depression)

questions.text: A 26-year-old student was found unresponsive by his roommate after a party. A physical examination at the hospital revealed constricted pupils with a heart rate of 62 BPM, blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg, and a respiratory rate of 8 per minute. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient's condition?

options.label: D
options.text: Forced alkaline diuresis with sodium bicarbonate

questions.explanation:
Opioid Overdose/ Poisoning

Cause

Clinical, accidental or suicidal overdose

Symptoms
  • Unconsiousness/coma
  • Miosis: Pin point pupil
  • Respiratory depression
  • Dry secretion in the eye/mouth
  • Urinary retention
  • Constipation
  • Flaccid muscles
  • Convulsions (in children)

Management

Acute overdose/poisoning: IV Naloxone (Antidote)

↓

Maintenance (Detoxification phase: To prevent withdrawal):

  • Opioids: Buprenorphine, Methadone, Tramadol
  • Non-Opioids- Clonidine, Lofexidine

↓

Abstinence (Prevent relapse):

  • DOC: Oral Naltrexone

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding opioid withdrawal symptoms is false? It is a life-threatening condition resulting from chronic opioid dependence Anxiety and irritability are common during early periods of opioid withdrawal. Bradycardia and Sweating are typical symptoms of opioid withdrawal. Buprenorphine is used to reduce withdrawal symptoms and cravings Naloxone is used to treat acute withdrawal symptoms and prevent future relapses.
questions.explanation:
Opioid withdrawal

Causes

Abruptly stopping chronic use of opioids, including pain medication or illegal drug abuse.

Onset
  • 6-12 hours: Short-acting opioids (heroin, fentanyl)
  • 24-48 hours: Long-acting opioids (oxycodone)

Symptoms
  • W (M): Mydriasis
  • I: Increased yawning (increase respiration), irritability
  • T: Hyperthermia, Tachycardia
  • H: Hyperventilation
  • D: Diarrhea
  • R: Rhinorrhea
  • A: Anxiety, sweating
  • W (M): Myalgia
  • L: Lacrimation

Management

Deaddiction:

  • Start on methadone (long-acting)/ buprenorphine (reduce craving)
  • Methadone can be continued safely in pregnant women.
  • Taper the dose
  • Beta-blocker, Clonidine (symptomatic treatment)
  • Naltrexone (Prevent relapse)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male came to the clinic complaining of constipation for several days. A few weeks ago, he experienced diarrhoea after returning from Thailand, which was resolved after taking loperamide and ornidazole. What medication is best suited for relieving this patient's symptoms
questions.explanation:

Bulk laxatives

Soluble (Psyllium)

Insoluble (wheat bran)

Retaining water in stools, increasing

Stool softeners or wetting agents

Decussate sodium

Decussate calcium

Promoting luminal water binding by detergent action and increasing stool bulk

Stimulant laxatives

Sodium picosulfate

Bisacodyl

Increasing intestinal peristalsis by acting in myenteric plexus; decreasing large intestine water absorption

Osmotic agents

Polyethyleneglycol (PEG)

Osmotic water binding

Mixed (not classified)

Dried plums

Stool bulking and osmotic action

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of Parkinson's disease complained of pain after he underwent a laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair a few hours ago. Shortly after taking medication for pain relief, he became agitated and started sweating. Physical examination revealed tachycardia, hyperreflexia, and myoclonus in the legs. Which of the following drugs was most likely given to this patient?
questions.explanation:
Drugs avoided with MAO inhibitors: (Due to risk of Serotonin syndrome)

  • Tramadol
  • Fentanyl, Meperidine
  • Tricyclic depressants (amitriptyline)
  • SSRI (sertaline, citalopram etc.)
  • Dextromethorphan
  • Linezolid
  • MDMA, LSD, amphetamine
  • Food: soy products, red wine, cheese
  • Pethidine (causes seizure with MAO-)
